description: Between October and April, the Maple Leafs play hockey in this arena, but be forewarned that obtaining game tickets is both difficult and expensive.

reviews.title: Great spot
text: Amazing facility. Great to stroll around and check out goods. Maple and bacon doughnuts are a revelation. The artwork made of old seats is really clever.

reviews.title: I’m glad it’s still there.
text: It’s not been a place for hockey for nearly 20 years or maybe longer but I’m glad it wasn’t torn down. The building was converted into a Loblaws grocery store (you can see Center ice in aisle 25) and as part of Ryerson University. Not much changed except the price of food. Inflation is insane right now.

reviews.title: Great Experience
text: If you are a hockey fan it would be worth a trip to visit a Leaf's game.  I happened to be in Toronto on work when I discovered the Blues were in town to play the Leafs.  It's one of those old time stadiums with very steep stairs.  But great site lines.  It was a Monday night and there was standing room only. They've done a cool thing by making a standing room only section behind the very top row and it was packed.  With a subway attached to the stadium it's amazing how many people you can move out of the area quickly. Fans appeared to be relatively nice to the visiting blues fans.  This was a nice surprised compared to other stadiums such as Chicago, Boston, etc.

reviews.title: Canadian Blind Hockey Nationals
text: What a beautiful piece of history being kept alive. Loved seeing all the Maple Leaf pictures around the building. My little boy was pretty excited to play hockey in the same building the Leafs once did. Not many little guys from Newfoundland can say they did that. Amazing memories made especially having Wendel Clark and Doug Gilmore come and drop the puck for the Select teams. That was the cherry on the cake. Stories and memories that will last a life time made during our tournament!!

reviews.title: Lovely building!
text: I just wanted to visit the old girl!  I am a Leafs fan from the UK & have only seen this building from the outside.  I was looking at the Ryerson Uni website & found out that you can do a self guided tour of the building!!  I save the PDF to my laptop, but on the day forgot to print it out.  I went to the reception & the guy behind kindly printed it out for me.  I found that the building seemed to have a presence.  Looking at all the photos & clips of history on the walls it felt weird.  I was asked to stop recording the basketball team that was practising in the court. Ooops!! If I had more time I would of taken my time to walk a bit more slowly & take it in!  I will be back I'm sure!!

reviews.title: Now part of Ryerson University
text: Walked around here and was amazed that Ryerson has purchased or leased maple leaf gardens. It doesn't look like they have done much to change things, it still has an old world charm to it.

reviews.title: History
text: Just going here for the history of the place.  Been here when younger for hockey games.  The feel of the history.  That is what I went for.

reviews.title: Visit
text: If your looking for a gym to workout in , Ryerson University gym is located in maple leaf gardens. $10 for a day pass. Excellent place to just visit or to workout

reviews.title: visiting the history of the home of the Toronto Maples Hockey team for decades including Stanley Cup victories.
text: You can feel the hockey history when walking around the building. The memories of the great hockey players like Charlie Conacher, Joe Primeau and all the others, which is a list too long to note in this email, who proudly donned a Leaf Jersey.

reviews.title: Maple leaf gardens  - a piece of Toronri's history
text: Bought by Ryeson Univeristy and Loblows this building has seen many hockey games played there - some lost, some won. The building also has been a venue for basketball games, music events etc
There is a viewing gallery and a shop selling Rams hockey items. It was also a venue for the Invictous games since they appeared in Canada. There is also a supermarket called loblows next door

reviews.title: Great piece of hockey history
text: Open to the public daily and free admission it is a must see for any true hockey fan, this is a legendary arena.  It has been re-purposed but you still get a great sense of the history worth the trip

reviews.title: Ideal place
text: It is historic and ideal to visit with lots of activities inside this place. Many people recommended so i went there

reviews.title: Change
text: The Maple Leaf Gardens has change. It is  now home to a giant food store. It used to be the place where you go to watch a Hockey game or go skating, now you can shop for food and goods. It has change a lot inside but the outside still remains the same. It think this is a nice place to visit.

reviews.title: Now Called the Mattamy Athletic Centre
text: This is where the Toronto Maple Leafs used to play their games, but the Gardens has recently been purchased by Ryerson University. They have changed the Gardens into their basketball arena and hockey rink for their home games.

reviews.title: An interesting visit
text: I was there for an event and was amazed at the location.  I loved to learn the history of the place, there's a lot of information and pictures and you can easily imagine how glorious the stadium was. There are some original items you can see.

reviews.title: Great place
text: A great gym and athletic centre with the constant reminder of the vast history of this building. It is extremely cool to be able to go and work out here, knowing the legends that have been in this building. Also the sports courts are very nice, well done.

reviews.title: Legendary
text: Gone are the hockey days from this hallowed arena. Now Loblaws has turned it into an uber glorious market. The grocery chain has made it a flagship of the company. Located in the middle of downtown Toronto with easy public access it has become an ideal spot to pick up a unique & delicious offering for your table at home.  Everything a good supermarket offers plus, plus, plus ! Go & spend time grocery shopping it will be lots of fun exploring new tastes. Ryerson University also shares the location with ample underground parking.

reviews.title: Worth a visit...
text: The old Maple Leaf Gardens is now converted to a flagship grocery store and an athletics facility for Ryerson University students.  Old photos of hockey players and rock concerts are on display if you walk around upstairs in the athletic facility.  Go to aisle 27 (or maybe 29) and you will find a red circle on the floor which indicates where centre ice was when the NHL played there. There is also some ready made food and an eating area.

reviews.title: Basketball at Maple Leaf Gardens
text: Watched wheelchair basketball here and loved the venue, who would have known there were floors of activity above a grocery store! Hard to understand the announcer and food selection limited but not outrageously expensive.

reviews.title: OH CANADA, WHAT A NIGHT TO REMEMBER, EH!
text: Maple Leaf Garden is now the Ryerson's Mathemy athletic center,  a fabulous and incredible athletic facilities for the Ryerson's students and public. It is also the site of the Canada vs America for the gold medal of the Pam Am basketball game. My husband and I decided at the last minute to abandon our comfortable armchairs and got tickets to see this historical event. It was a night of NO REGRETS. $80 each for the best seats in the house, center court, with no obstructions in our sightline. The court is in mint condition which in the winter reverses to a skating and ice hockney arena. The seats are comfortable and in tiered so no problems with beehives hairdos or giant heads. The place was rocking with a dilirious, supersonic hyped and thunderous crowd. There were a sea of red maple leaf, big and small, in the hair, on the entire or part of the body, on the face and in the hand. It was LOUD!!! Who said that Torontonians are indifferent and don't know how to party?!? There were anxious OMG moments as well as a lot of thunderous 'Defence' and 'Cheer' but in the end we were rewarded by our own basketball superwomen with a historical first GOLD! ALL HAIL LADIES, YOU ALL DO US PROUD, WHAT A SWEET CANADIAN MOMENT!!!

reviews.title: Packed food
text: I am in awe, to realize that their food is frozen, I love their salad bar and it was the first time I buy the packed pasta Marinara and Rigatoni pasta, and was shocked that it was frozen, after hearing it for 90 sec, I was been able to find ice chucks in it. Too bad, I thought it's all fresh, unless if frozen food is the new fresh.

reviews.title: A grocery store with a 100 years of history!!!
text: What a great place to shop!!!  The place is filled with the atmosphere of the maple leafs gardens and if you look closely enough you will see some of the old chairs mounted on the wall in the shape of a maple leaf.

The grocery is top not with a great selection a fresh, frozen and packaged goods - that said for the life of me I couldn't find nacho chips and I looked everywhere.  So frustrating...the store is large and I mean really large, make sure to give yourself time.  There is a liquor store upstairs where you can buy beer and wine which makes getting ready for dinner or a night out easier - one stop shop.  Keep in mind this is one of the most expensive groceries in Toronto.  Don't buy their baked goods - just do a google search on market place Loblaws changing best before dates.

reviews.title: Grocery store filled with history
text: You're in town and looking to pick up groceries but want to take in some of Toronto's best hockey history this is a spot for you to go.  Don't forget to swing by and Thor the dot marking center ice

reviews.title: Amazing
text: I am not a Maple Leafs fan but I am a fan of hockey. The Loblaws has a great cafe with a lot of options and reasonable prices.  In addition there are many pictures of the history of Maple Leaf Gardens. Also if you spend 20 or more your parking is free for an hour and a half.

reviews.title: its a loblaws..
text: if u need groceries or to visit ryerson gym..this is your place.. not sure y its on trip advisor.. but...

reviews.title: Loblaws at Maple Leaf Gardens
text: Raves for a Super-Market? Just go and be amazed. When the Leafs moved out, Ryerson University and Loblaws teams up to redevelop the Maple Leaf Gardens. With a rick and all the seats - ground, mezzanine and balcony - removed the area was huge, and that's the Loblaws. A ten meter tall cheese case pais with another 25 meters of cheese. Sixty different breads. Fresh sushi. A fish section that matches any dedicated fish store anywhere. Prepared foods galore. Oh! and a huge chain store with ten manned check-out lines.
An acrylic red floor, great lighting, 3 meter aisles.
As food halls go, this is better than Harrods! 'nuff said?

reviews.title: Great grocery store with hostory
text: If you are a hockey fan and used to watch games at maple leaf gardens then you have to stop by loblaws grocery store. Look on the wall to your upper right as you enter from church and Carlton and see the maple leaf made out of the salvaged blue chairs that one used to sit in to watch games. Go for a walk around the store and look for the big orange dot on the floor which is the original dot location for centre ice. Is not where you would expect it. Is closer to the end of the store away from the veggie section. Loblaws does it right!

reviews.title: Loblaw mapleLeaf garden
text: The most attractive hyper market on the planet the best location the best variety the best mood for shopping with the widest selection and in the middle of Toronto the old maple leaf stadium it d the land Mark in
Toronto of not in Canada
They have a word nut selection as for rifai nuts on their shelves

reviews.title: What a transformation
text: We watched hockey in this building in 1993 and 1996 and were disappointed that it had fallen into disrepair since the Leafs moved out in 1999. However we were intrigued to learn that it had been transformed into a Loblaws supermarket with an ice rink upstairs.
The shop is a typical supermarket apart from aisle 25 which has a circle marking where centre ice had been in the original rink.

On entering the old main doors, we went up an escalator to a reception area where extremely helpful staff advised us how we could see the transformation. On one of the walls above the escalators is a row of red seats from the old rink and on reaching level 4 we found a lovely rink with plenty of spectator seating and what looks like great sight lines. Ryerson University use the rinks and it is also used by the local community.
We spent a good while looking around the building and were pleased to see many photos of the old rink, keeping history alive.
This is a fantastic transformation and we were delighted to see a great old building being put to great use,

reviews.title: A Rare Remaining Landmark
text: There was a time when Hockey could be seen live with families and the Toronto Maple Leafs would open on Saturdays to let kids see the practices. Hockey was affordable in grey seats not too far away fom the ice. And Toronto had the Stanley Cup 1967. Then look around and remember the Beatles in the City and a few of the great leadership conventions of Canada's leading political parties.
Today the exterior remains while the inside is home to a food shopping store and Ryerson. Not a destination spot but a rare building not yet torn down for condos.

reviews.title: Great Old Original 6 Barn
text: You can still feel the blue and white history oozing from the walls of this old majestic palace.  Now a LCBO and Loblaws Grocery store , but still quite accessible.  Many historical markings throughout, such as centre ice and concert postings (such as the Beatles) throughout.  Met Doug Gilmour last week in Loblaws at his book signing, so you never know who you'll see there.

reviews.title: Trveled here a few times during y sons Hockey career
text: Exciting place with a lot of history. After closing my account by mistake, I am recreating my account and experiences

reviews.title: Love the old Gardens
text: It's wonderful they still use the old gardens    We love this place. The Loblaws is amazing with the cheese wall and ACE bakery. We never miss the opportunity to visit when in Toronto.

reviews.title: Although repurposed, still has a lot of history
text: Maple Leaf Gardens is now home to the Mattamy Athletic Centre and Loblaws.   Still a lot of history to be found inside and worth a visit if you're a fan of hockey history.

reviews.title: Mixed Emotions visiting The Gardens
text: I have not been at the Gardens since one of the last Leaf games.  I drove by it many times and it was kind of sad to see this old building just stand there seemingly lonely and empty.  I know its been "re-purposed" and its home of the Ryerson team as well as a loblaws and a community centre, but I just did not want to admit that the Maple Leaf Gardens are no more.  So... I was walking past it couple days ago, and I decided to go in... walked right in through the main entrance and all kinds of emotions came on, it was very weird.... I was able to walk all around the new gym and right into the rink.  It was pretty awesome.. Standing there with the perfect sheet of ice and "THAT" ceiling above you .... almost as it was so long ago... I had no idea what a great job they did preserving the feel of the Gardens.... and you can just walk in off the street and walk right in and reminisce.. ...  I'm so glad I did that... I will have to come back to watch a live hockey game at this place... if you have not seen this place, walk in, check it out.  it will bring back some memories.

reviews.title: Great place
text: Visited Loblaws Maple Leaf Gardens one of the best supermarkets I have ever been to. They make fresh bread daily in the Ace bakery, amazing meals made fresh everyday in the kitchen. Such a great store to visit right in the heart of Toronto's downtown, a must see for foody's and hockey fans

reviews.title: Perfect
text: There is a lot of options to buy something to eat at night, it's very beautiful inside there, I loved

reviews.title: Passing look
text: For those looking for a bit of hockey history, this place mostly misses the mark.  There is still a hockey rink in the Ryerson Athletic Center, and there is an arrangement of MLG's original seats in the Loblaws, but mostly it is worth only a passing look.

reviews.title: Fun and Comfortable
text: We went last week for the men's final of the curling match.  The seats were roomy and comfortable, view of the ice was excellent, sound system good,  snack bars located near the seats and washrooms nearby too.  There is parking below ground.

reviews.title: FROM MLG TO THE MAC
text: Just spent 3 days at the former Maple Leaf Gardens attending the National Woman's Volleyball Championships and WOW...what a great venue. Since it's rejuvenation, this National Historic Site at 60 Carlton St. is as vibrant as ever!  A high end Loblaws occupies the street level and offers an in-store ACE Bakery and fantastic prepared foods for take-out. There's also a Nutella dessert kiosk making made to order crepes. Upstairs they have a cooking school and an LCBO. Ryerson University leases the remainder of the Gardens ( now called the Mattamy Athletic Centre) and they spared no expense. The second floor houses a huge gymnasium and fitness centre and on the 3rd floor is an NHL sized ice rink under the original domed ceiling of the Gardens. Ryerson made sure to pay homage to the site by keeping some original seats intact and displaying lots of old pictures. If you're in the area stop by and have a look. You will be very happy you did.
